text.quote: 2,711 columns forming a vast mazelike Holocaust memorial, with an underground exhibition room.
google: It's impactful, and interactive in an unexpected way. Walking through it gets eerie. But there is hardly any accompanying info (I did not make it inside the memorial, so that's on me) and many of the blocks are falling apart, like they were …

I think this monument and the museum are great. The museum is really good and impressive. I almost cried, because of the sad stories and it was just super stunning. If you have the chance to visit the museum and the monument please just do …

For the gravity that is the Holocaust, this memorial seems very underwhelming. It's neat and clean and all, but it won't make you feel the impact that the events had on all those lives. If you want some real impactful stuff, visit …
trip: The monuments are impressive and amazing. The story around it is touching and terrible. Worth a visit
While I appreciate the sentiment, the meaning of this memorial was lost on me. It does not make the powerful statement that I have felt at other memorial installations.

The memorial itself is symbolic, but it is a shame that people sit on top of the blocks and take photos and people allow their kids to run around and play games as it is takes away from the serious nature of the place. The information centre underneath the memorial is excellent
I suppose the memorial is meant to be immersive, you have to walk into the maze, let yourself be swallowed up by the stones. Impressive memorial.

We had been before and I have to say it's not the best memorial I ve Ever seen , and that has nothing to do with the shame of the holocaust it's just looks blank and says nothing .there's no emotion coming through from the artists all .. Sorry
This is a stark reminder of man's inhumanity. It is a large sad, symbolic display. But, it wasn't designed for enjoyment.

No review would give you an idea of what this place does to you. It’s truly fitting for such a tragedy. It’s interpretation is completely down to the individual. I recommend that when you visit this memorial, you do so with friends, however you should split up and walk through
Visited the memorial as part of a walking tour which was very interesting to listen to the guide with his facts.

It is hard to think you are under 10 minutes walk away from the Brandenburg Gate and the bustle of the Unter den Linden when you get here. The architecture is quite unique and impressive and you can also go to a basement level for an exhibition.
Beautiful architectural monument to pay tribute to the Holocaust, lots of youngsters taking selfies and playing around but better that kind of happiness than sadness

I understand the significance of this memorial but I think they could have done a better job. Not much to see. Contemporary. You can essentially see it from the car windows. 2,711 slabs of concrete on uneven ground. That was it. I didn’t understand it.
didn't do the tour just went around the blocks , fairly busy but bearable , i wouldn't do it again in truth

Its a very sombre place to be and reminded of our dark history. In a way, it teaches us a lot. The sad horror that the Jews and homosexuals had to undergo. Must visit , Just stand in the midst and reflect on the past of what they persecuted went through. The memorial is located
Its worth a visit to know why this is here. A bit of history and sadness. Go with a tour guide or a walking tour to know more about the place

Wow - what a unique memorial and an incredibly sobering experience! This is a must-do in Berlin, for sure. You enter alone, left to wander confusedly to contemplate the terrible atrocities on human life. We went here in August 2019 as part of "Alla Tours" all day tour of Berlin

Germany’s capital was at the heart of some of humanity’s darkest days, and monuments and museums are open to commemorate the countless victims. The place to go to experience the sheer scale of loss of World War II is to visit the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe.

The Holocaust Memorial occupies a significant area of Berlin's very center, only one block south from the Brandenburg gate and Reichstag, among several major embassies. It was established (built) at the beginning of this century, on no man's land, in fact on the death strip

This didn't create any emotional response and was more like a modern art installation. Nearby construction didn't help and visitors were treating it like a maze and were not respectful of the monument.
Unsettling, unnerving and thought provoking. As you walk through the structure, it becomes overwhelming. This visit will stay with you for a while.
Definitely a must see in Berlin - a monument that lets you interpret this fascinating piece of art your own way.

This is memorial, not instagram central so please be respectful (no jumping from one pillar to another or funny videos). It is not a maze but a memorial. It was sad to see how tourists behaved. In terms of best time to go to see fewer people I would say at sunrise
Makes you think about lot of things.. Interesting to see and walk into. I recommend to visit this place. Easy to get to.
cinder blocks that create a burial atmosphere . It is not an obvious attraction - one should look, sit and contemplate. This is about reflection and a message of remembrance.

Beautiful and moving monument to the Jews who perished during the Holocaust. Do visit. I've heard sometimes people aren't respectful and are busy taking selfies, oblivious to the meaning of where they are. Fortunately this was not the case when we visited.
Very poignant memorial to the Jews suffering during the war. The true stories and real extracts of letters written by the Prisoners brings it home. Well worth a visit.
Close to the Brandenburg Gate in the heart of Berlin you will find the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe. A must to see!

A very thought provoking museum. It recounted the stories of many Jewish families and their fate, providing evidence in the form of audio, visual and written accounts. My teenage daughter found it very informative and left with a far greater understanding of what the Jews

This is pretty bleak memorial when you think about what its actually for but to be honest unless you read up or are told this is a memorial to the Jews you would assume it was some modern art. We wondered round the cubes and some are massive. Didn't have time to go to the
First view you wonder why, but start walking through blocks and it becomes a very haunting experiance

Cubes stand in rows, too numerous to count, I found it rather an odd memorial, by design, yet I was moved by it. How do you represent such an horror in today’s world..? I have to say I was pretty shocked to see people seating on top of the cubes, eating and drinking, to me that

A 1 Min walk from the Brandenburg Gate this amazing tribute and memorial is free and very little said about it when there. American embassy is opposite if that helps. Definitely somewhere to visit in the day. Not sure about the evening.

I didn't like this at first and apparently I'm not the only one - it's been quite controversial. It felt flat, grey and unrepresentative of the horrors it memorialises. But, as you walk in and down - become immersed in grey concrete, realise it is far bigger and deeper than you

The concrete blocks are just the surface of this memorial. Find your way to the underground area to really be impacted by this memorial. Includes an explanation of the calculated, persistent, evil persecutions of the mid 20 century, and personal stories of some of those who were

Just a short walk from Potsdammer Platz or the Brandenburg Gate. A contemplative walk round the blocks of varied height may not be on the top of everyone's list of things to see. When you have done your walk cross the busy road to the Tier Garten, her you will find another

The blocks above ground seem a bit odd at first and the undulating ground messes with the mind. Is it meant to convey the disoriented, twisted treatment of the Jews? It would have worked had it not been for youngsters (teenagers, not kids) treating it as a playground or maze,
This was really interesting and more moving than you might think. Worth the time to walk through and think about the Murdered Jews of Europe.

I guess this will be in you top 5 places to see when in Berlin. It is basically just a walk around and not much info there you will have to read up or join a tour to know more. But the Memorial place is done very creatively.

This was a quite stunning part of a walking tour which we really did not expect to be so big. The slabs which make up the memoriar are various sizes - 2700 slabs 7ft x 3ft with heights up to nearly 5 metres - in the light we had the effect was stunning - high contract. The

The memorial is quiet from the busy city of Berlin. It is peaceful once you get into the memorial. The way they presented what had happened is done well. The muesum is free and is not too long, yet not too short. It is a must see.
Okay, knowing the history this place puts you thinking how sick people can be to each others. Must visit when in Berlin.

We passed by this memorial on a cold, wet and very windy day which made this large area of concrete coffin shapes concrete blocks in different sizes even more impressive. The underground exhibition will tell you individual stories. A must visit when in Berlin.
terribly ugly place... not maintained, dirty and full of tourists for selfies.... the worst place in berlin
a must visit for everypne who visits Berlin. This tour has testimonies of the people directly affected by the darkest chapter of mankind.

A very intelligent, thought provoking and emotional place to visit. Would be easy to get lost in numbers but while giving you the figures it also vividly describes how the holocaust developed and the impact it had on individuals and families. The audio is only 3 euros and is
A solemn, cold thought provoking memorial! This memorial is spread over quite a large area. It is a series of coffin shaped grey concrete blocks which are open to your own interpretation.

You almost stumble upon it-on the pavement looking back at the Reichstag and Brandenburg tor... then you wonder what it is? And then it dawns on you- diff size blocks alleys of narrow spaces solitary monoliths... a grave a tomb a marker a doorway ... none of them, all of them..
Words cannot explain how moving and sad this memorial is,It is handled so well. All who visit Berlin must take the time to see what people had to endure under the Nazis.

This is a must see memorial to the murdered Jews across mainland Europe. Very informative, very sad and very harrowing experience. I strongly recommend the audio guide, Quite an unbeliaveble experience
Must visit for a history lover. Adjacent to Brandenburg Gate and Hitler's bunker where he committed suicide

I want to go back, we visited it with a free walking tour and we didn't have enough time to get lost, I think you really need to spend some time alone to think about what happened and how cruel was the Holocausto.
I was very sad walking thru here especially when i heard all about the history of the Jews who were murdered.
Very insightful and moving tribute to what happened. We opted for the audio description and you can’t put into words how to feel about it. You must visit this when in Berlin.
A well thought out memorial to the victims of the holocaust, provides more questions than answers. The architect has provided a layout that leaves you guessing as to what it represents.

Very thought provoking and extremely interesting memorial. We didn’t have to wait too long to get in and we opted for the audio service which was worth using. Everyone who visits Berlin should visit here. The stories and the details are heartbreaking but should be told. Highly
I'm not quite sure what the creator of this memorial with hundreds of grey concrete blocks intended to portray, but that makes it open to discussion and interpretation.

Obviously the subject of the museum displays is extremely sad, but it is definitely worth visiting. The displays are excellent, there's lots of information and even quotes from letters written by victims of the tragedy. The memorial itself is beautiful in its harrowing

How to make 6,000,000 not just a number? The illustration these concrete blocks symbolises, left us all silent, reflective, and with a long-lasting memory of the cruelty that man can make. The 10-y boy was silent, and then questioning/discussing - giving words to the grief.

This is a true reminder of some of the worst of German history. It is a poignat place and alows for reflection. Well worth a visit. It is a shame that security staff have to, at times, remind people of the need for respect at such a historic sight.
We were here early morning (around 7:30) and it was deserted. Easier to get pictures when not lots of people around.
Within walking distance from several must-see s in Berlin, even if you're on a tight schedule like us, do pass by. Interesting arrangement of grey slabs of varying heights. Be evoked.
A beautiful memorial and museum. I was in tears at some of the stories I read walking around. A must see.

As part of an excellent walking tour we stopped and was given an explanation that the memorial is not purely for the Jewish lost in Germany but throughout Europe. The most disturbing fact came when it was explained that some columns are crumbling due to the weather (we’d noticed
The memorial is some sort of maze type accumulation of large cubes. Why this was designed for a memorial I’m not entirely sure I guess it’s open for interpretation. It’s cool to get lost within it

If you would like to visit the sad history of Berlin, you will need to spend few minutes here. Easy to approach, however it is not a place you would spend a lot of time at. No restaurants, toilets nearby, the area is not covered. Would not recommend for families. If you are not
I’ve been twice, and it’s more moving and relevant now than even 11 years ago. Don’t miss this stunning confluence of art, human horror, and hope.
So many stones makes you wonder that where all these people counted at all as humans or were they just pieces.

We visited as part of a guided tour. Most helpful advice our guide gave us, was to make our own translation and ideas of the monument. Worth taking the time and effort for if you do nothing else relating to the holocaust.

Lest I am misnderstood - to even have such a memorial in the German capital demonstrates the rehabilitation of this great nation after the trauma of 1933 -45, and I do not for one minute denigrate or disapprove of holocaust memorials - but I'm not really sure of the artistic
A very somber place bit amazing to walk through , don’t be disrespectful though and jump across stones for photos we saw a few do this but were swiftly told off by security !
Thought provoking and a must for any visit to Berlin. Give yourself 1/2 hour to walk through the site

We've all seen the documentaries on TV etc. but this memorial and the "exhibition" gave the extent of what happened a totally new meaning. Very sombre experience and one that ideally all humanity should experience to make us all think about what happened and prevent anything
What a important monument and how important it is that we never forget. It’s both beautiful and sad to visit.
Very unique, not sure how one designs this, creative ideas. Blocks represent coffins. Easy to walk through, worth a quick stop.
A must see when in Berlin. This museum is very well laid out and creative and is a fitting tribute to Europe’s murdered Jews. The audio guide was great and would recommend paying the €3 for this.

I was amazed at the impact this had. You need to experience it yourself as it promotes a personal reaction. The designer had no rationale so it would be arrogant of me to propose my own. The one thing I really felt angry about was a family playing hide and seek and pretending
Really? A Holocaust memorial in Germany? Surely they could have designed something better, a more appropriate memorial? I visited auschwitz before visiting this memorial. Disappointed

A sobering memorial and learning experience - street level is a stark visual of a sea of “coffins” to represent the Murdered Jews. Below is a small yet powerful museum. Take the audio tour, we much as I thought I knew, I learned more. They pick out the very personal stories of a

I found this to be a very moving display. This is an large (perhaps 2 acre) undulating display of various sizes of cubes. It should be viewed in a quiet, sobering atmosphere. It often is not; this is not the fault of the memorial. The structure is a place that also attracts

My wife, son, daughter and I visited The Holocaust Memorial - Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in December 2019. I had visited here in August 2018. My wife, son and daughter seemed very reflective as they walked around the stone blocks. I noticed that there is a lot of

The Holocaust Memorial is a stunning tribute to the people who lost their lives during this terrible event. The stone blocks seem to go on and on in the distance, every channel has a different size and alignment. A marvellous tribute to The Holocaust event.
No words... Beautiful Monument to those who lost their lives and suffered through this time. Easy access and very busy in summer and high season, but worth visiting

As you walk through the rows, notice that the monuments begin to swallow you up gradually as the path sinks and the monuments rise, just as gradually as Nazi mindsets swept into Central Europe and eradicated millions. Very simple, very moving.
In the middle of a busy city a haunting hush surrounds you as you enter. A fitting tribute. History at its best.

The place is full of people taking selfies but even that doesn't take away the feeling you get there. Each one of us had a different understanding of what the blocks represent but everyone was very impressed.

Theres no explanation as to why theres sk many columns, why they're the different sizes. I really like this concept as it provokes you to make your own interpretation. Very clever, invoking remembrance.
thought provoking meander through the walkways close to the Brandenberg Gate and Reichstag. very peaceful although next to main road

This was one of the monuments that was a must see when I was in Berlin. Honestly it was a little to hard since google map didn't make it very clear and luckily I was with a local who showed me. It's right next to the Gate and you can't really miss it! It was really nice to walk
Loved it. The memorial itself is quite overwhelming when you stand in it. Don’t miss the museum. The line moves quickly, it’s free and it’s both emotional and informative.

I had walked past this monument without realising what it was and driven past it on a couple of times. It was only when google maps pointed it out that I crossed the road and realised that the blocks of stone was the memorial. Personally this is an example of a lost opportunity
A must see!! Very impressive and heart wrenching. Something that should never happen again anywhere in this world.
To fully appreciate this Memorial - walk in and out of the columns and feel the magnitude and sadness of what took place.

Visited this memorial on a dreary rainy day. First impressions were not really that good a lot of concrete blocks but once you start going through the lines of them and thinking about the people it does get to you
Definitely worth the trip too see this monument of this black time in history and all the lost life’s.
I don’t think words can describe how sad and beautiful this place is. Couldn’t imagine not going to Berlin and visiting. Must see

At first glance you think it is just a bunch of concrete blocks and it is nothing out of the ordinary. When you realise each block is different, all the blocks are angled separately and the walkways alter every which way, you can understand the confusion they must have felt. We

We expected this memorial to have some sort of history boards with a bit of information on when this was built why etc. Instead it is just great blocks of concrete that you can walk through. A little bit boring but good if you want to take photos.

I walked through the memorial on two or three occasions on my last visit, the large blocks and rolling paths are interesting in that as you progress your lost in thoughts and leave today’s world behind. A solemn reminder of a horrific chapter of human history.

I cannot leave enough stars or a high enough review of this great place. I was truly blown away by the memorial, and the museum underneath is absolutely amazing. A large museum, i paid the €3 for the audio guide and it was well worth it. First hand stories of the holocaust,

This is a stunning memorial with symmetrical architecture to remember those who died. The colours used in the architecture really represent the dark history of The Holocaust. This is the most stunning design memorial I have easily have seen.

This was an amazing experience it was free although you can leave a voluntary contribution. We paid €6 for the English speaking headphones. The information was so informative. I found it very emotional for obvious reasons. I have recently been to Poland and to Auschwiitz So this

This was one of the sights we wanted to see when we're in Berlin was the Holocaust memorial, was humbling to be stood amongst it and think of all those ppl that lost there lives during the Holocaust. If in Berlin you have to visit.
An excellent memorial and grand in size. The backstory is equally as powerful. Walk the paths and reflect.
there is a memorial you can go down into but the queue can be long , it is very moving and worth a visit
A very humbling experience well worth a visit. The information centre which is below the memorial is also worth going to. We did the audio tour for only 3€.
The genius of this memorial is in its design, which could be interpreted in a myriad of ways and underscores the reality and tragedy of the holocaust.

visit this place and remembered what happened in rohingnya or uighur.. make me thinking about humanity. i always hate politics. its the main reason of human conflict. this monument became the reminder how bad poltics can be
Very moving space and the underground museum is incredibly moving and set up very well. A must do whilst in Berlin.
Who would have thought rectangular blocks of concrete could paint such a picture. Certainly worth experiencing and taking a little time out of rushing round Berlin

Walking between the blocks in the cold air of Berlin gives you the right moment to think about history and have a silent moment for both: the jews and the germans. Judgeless. Nude. Like the big grey stone blocks.
Great experience, very moving and very unique due to the arqueitecture of the monument, never seen something quite like it before. Would go again if a visit Berlin.

Whilst the stones are thought provoking, it is well worthwhile going to the museum underneath the memorial. The description of the museum is understated in the blah blah. The exhibition is very clever in its storytelling. A must see
This is one of the must see places and every individual feels the place in a different way. Pray for the people who suffered.

The memorial is a must see in Berlin. It is a very poignant momument to those who lost their lives. You can walk inbetween the stones in a labyrinth and in the middle of it you can really feel the pain and huge loss of life. It's such a sombre place but be weary of idiots

Any visit to Berlin must include several stops! Well, the Holocaust Memorial is certainly one of them. I struggle going to places like this since I grieve when I think about how evil humanity can be, but then I realize this is exactly why I must visit it and pay respect to those
Poignant and moving a period in time that should never be forgotten or allowed to be forgotten An excellent memorial to those who faced such inhumane treatment
The monument looks like a labyrinth, which translates what anti-Semitism causes. Walking there I could feel the pain of the loss of several human generations.

The memorial is very impressive, and really quite awe-inducing. It's sombre, as you'd expect. There is a museum but the queue was quite long. If you go, be prepared to lose yourself - and also watch out for very disrespectful people taking selfies.
Not sure what to write. It is simply an absorbing place to visit. Strange that such an emotive subject is the subject of what appears, initially, to be a series of blocks.
Highly recommend to put into context the events of the holocaust. Allow at least 2 hours to be able to make the most of the huge amount of information there is to read
A tour of the visitor centre below the steelae explains the design of this thought provoking memorial . A very moving experience that should be compulsary education for young people .

I visited this with an open mind, and wasn't disappointed. Its a huge field of stelae of all different heights closely packed over undulating terrain. Its worth walking into and around the claustrophobic centre to get a sense of the true confusion of the memorial. We didn't

Apparently this monument was many years in the planning and approval. Thank goodness it was approved as it is an incredibly moving experience as well as being architecturally impressive. A good way to approach it is from the Brandenburg Gate corner and make your first journey
This memorial is quite sobering. It’s open to interpretation which makes you think even more. There are more than 2,000 concrete blocks and (according to our tour guide) no two blocks are the same.

We visited the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe while we were in Berlin and were glad to have included it in our itinerary. It was haunting to look across the hundreds and hundreds of stone blocks while considering all that the Jews have endured. Definitely worth a visit

The Holocaust Memorial is close to the Brandenburg Gate. It has 2,000+ grey slabs in a sloping plot at different heights and angles. There are rules for the site, like not standing in the slabs etc. There is a museum there too. We can learn from history.
Visited as part of a walking town. An overwhelming place that’s makes you feel enclosed. An interesting piece of art

Telling the stories of the Holocaust with personal perspectives, family histories, letters and photographs. Very quiet and respectful. It is very sad and overwhelming but tells the story of how the holocaust affected so many families all over the world.

A thought provoking memorial to the millions of members of the Jewish community murdered during the Holocaust. Would thoroughly recommend taking time to walk through the concrete blocks and reflect on the messages it drives to portray.

Absolutely fantastic memorial. Beautiful and well thought out but what really makes it is the museum underneath. Just turn up, no reservation needed and it’s totally free. Completely moving and very informative. It gave a full view of the war for those who know little and had
Visit the information centre under the memorial to learn more about the history of the Jewish and Roma people in world war 2. It was very moving and informative.

One of the many places visited by us whilst in Berlin, this memorial felt eerie and also very thought provoking,let us hope that something like this and what it stands for never happens again, peace to all.
You will not leave this site unmoved. Hard to read the letters of the victims, but think everyone who visits Berlin needs to experience it.
Great place and very nice don't forget to visit the underground museum. You can't skip this great piece of history.
I didn’t take as much time here as it was raining when I visited, but I would have liked to find (if it was available?) some information on the memorial. Very nice design.
Very nice monument, pleasing architecturally to the eye. A must see when going to Berlin. A little isolated from the rest of the tourist objectives but nice to see.
The design pays off in making you feel consumed by darkness, a very interesting concept for a memorial

First, we had to queue in the rain to gain access down the stairs to the museum. Fitting, with the air of sombreness perhaps, but I felt sombre enough without getting drenched. The exhibits were low key - I especially liked the lit areas of floor where you could see enlarged
This unique memorial in its scope and scale is very sobering. It is designed for reflection as well as impact and both are powerful.

The Memorial for the Holocaust is a tribute to all the souls who were murdered in the yesteryears. The 2711 concrete blocks is a reminder of all theJewish victims form the era of World War 2. The museum underneath the memorial is also worth a visit. However it was a shame to

The sculpture park is an amazing monument. But the museum underneath is where the emotion and power are at this memorial. It’s a free museum and you have to wait a little but trust me it will be worth it. The museum lays out the timeline of the holocaust but also shares
This Memorial for the Holocaust is a place that gives you a special feeling. With 2711 concrete blocks they remember the Jewish victims form WWII. Just walk around in silence. The entrance is free.

A very sombre memorial to walk amongst and give thought to the events that made it necessary. Easy to find and lends itself well to secluding yourself from the city around you and reflecting on why this memorial is needed. The current world seems to be forgetting the horrors

This is a very well done Memorial to Holocaust victims. The museum underneath is a must visit as past of getting the micro perspective on the effect on individual families. It is hard to grasp the tragedy as a whole, But the museum puts it into the perspective of the individual.
A very different memorial but very significant. Lets not forget the terrible things that happened and make these places a reflection time and not a selfie time
Interesting memorial, the stones represent whatever you want it to represent, there is a exhibition under the memorial free of charge,well worth seeing.
Well worth taking 20 minutes out to walk through the memorial and contemplate human actions. All sound seems to disappear.
I wasn't sure what to expect but this was a very good, calming exhibit. Although, we had to tell people to get off the stones as we felt it was disrespectful.
The undulating landscape combined with the different size and height of the slabs give you a feeling of being completely disorientated.
Worth a visit when in Berlin. Easy to get lost within. We walked through the memorial and really took in what it stood for.
A memorial to the Holocaust, very modern in design, full of light and shadows, open to interpretation
We learnt a lot about the effect of the holocaust on Jewish families. Really interesting learning about things I’ve not learnt about before. Highly recommend
I only knew of the external slabs and had no idea there was a whole information / exhibition of stories and explanation of what happened and individuals stories. Phenomenal

We were surprised at the huge size of the Memorial and spent more time than we expected walking through it (it draws you in). The way the paths undulate through the variable stone is very creative, and in a different setting would almost seem whimsical--however the overall
This art installation is simple and creepy at the same time. It's infuriating when you realise the horrors we permitted as humans.
Emotive and powerful site to see and remember. Free to visit the memorial but there was long queues for the underground museum.
Lovely cast memorial with good information on surrounding walls. Queue to get into free underground museum was huge do we didn’t wait. Lots of lour OST’s and tourist board there
Spent lot of time at this memorial. Respectful and emotive time spent here. Very beautifully arranged columns and was clean.

A surprising memorial. When you arrive you are struck with the thought - really that is it. I would encourage you to walk through it. The height of the blocks and the undulation of the paths will surprise you. Very clever memorial.
This is a must-see, the monument is very imposing and important to remember and contemplate and not forget the holocaust.

Strange in some ways, but walking through it, you forget you're in the middle of a big city and it goes weirdly quiet - unless you suddenly walk into someone crossing your path and jump a mile! Quite moving to walk through, and some good opportunities if you're into photography.

This isn’t the kind of place that you ‘recommend visiting’ in the normal sense but I do feel that everyone should go as history should be acknowledged and hopefully learnt from. We visited late afternoon as the final light of the day was disappearing. There were still a large

From the pictures this does not look like a very interesting memorial BUT once you are there and walk thru the memorial you will take away a very profound experience. It is a must "walk thru" memorial.

A quite extraordinary transition happens when you walk into and around within this monument. There are a few respectful rules written on the pavement outside but no explanations. Follow your own route through the monument to discover your feelings about the catastrophe that it
Not making big impression. Maybe night time its better, but to be honest I am wondering why such monument are being constructed.

Was disapointed with this as even though poignant felt the blocks of stone could be at least marble and maybe highlight the names of those who were deported from Berlin to be engraved would have meant more, got a feeling it was more of a modern art statement than a memorial

This memorial site is highly impressive, mainly because of its size and simplicity - straight lines and grey cement. Walking among the many tombstones makes it an internal experience, unlike watching an exhibition in a museum.
This was my first visit to Berlin. A friend of a friend who lives in Berlin took me to see the monument. I was not aware of the monument so I am glad he took me.
This is a interesting place to visit, however I found the behaviour of some people very disrespectful for somehting that is a memorial to the dead!
It is an intense emotional walk through this memorial. The only thing is the disrespectful people who are screaming and climbing the memorial... I'll never understand the lack of respect...
It was so interesting to learn more about this topic and so important to be informed about the facts. Find a knowledgeable guide!
Great place to have fun at all ages and have great vibe of games and enjoyment . Place to visit with friends and enjoy surroundings
Another piece of art to make money for this city. Millions of people have been killed in the past years after World War 2, but no statue of piece of art for that.....a waste of space.
Understated, moving experience. Important window into this historic time. Elie Weisel's quote at the entrance: "It happened. Therefore it could happen again."
The memorial is very poignant with a lot of hidden meanings to find for yourself. Appropriate and 100% worth a visit

This is next to Brandenburg gate. I real labyrinth of monuments that you can wander through. It's somber and good to see that it is centrally located. My son's and I wandered through but if you have small children keep them close as you can get lost in here.
Very impressive. We walked by this sight by night and were aware of the historical meaning of this sight. Recommend reading about this before visiting for sure. Bonus: we spotted a fox too.

The pictures I had seen prior didn’t do this monument justice. When you walk between the blocks the path Goes up and down (undulates). It’s easy to feel isolated after a few turns. Really an eerie effect.

The designer of this memorial has done a fantastic job. It is a very eerie sight and has been designed so as you can interpret the memorial however you like. Personally for me, the different sized concrete blocks made me feel very alone and lost. It’s a poignant memorial and
It's very powerful and beautiful memorial place. You feel sad when you come to this place and see this but I think its very important after all.

To view this memorial from a distance it doesn’t look all that interesting but you have to walk amongst the blocks to really immerse yourself in the place. This is a memorial to murdered jews - other memorials are in the area for other persecuted groups.
This is a unique piece of art that you really must see and FEEL. Walk between the stones and see how it is closing on you, really amazing!
This is a very surreal site to visit. While I was walking through the aisles in total silence, I could not begin to explain the feels I had. You need to go and visit to see and feel for yourself.

Did not see the inside/downstairs of the monument due to crowds, but reading and walking around the area was tough to do
An amazing artistic representation of the Jewish experience during the Holocaust. Definitely visit the info centre too!
This was def on my bucket list of must sees when in Berlin and it didn't disappoint. Immerse yourself amongst the stones and feel the quiet and reverence. I was brought to tears. So moving.

This is the best public work of art (and memorial) I've experienced. The scale and disorientation, when wandering amongst the blocks, works perfectly. It is eerie but moving - the conceptual element is very clever, without being clunky or patronising. Visiting the Bundestag
Interesting memorial. It doesn’t look that impressive from the edges but when you walk through it it creates a completely different feel and is peculiarly somber.

It is a powerful experience coming to this monument. A mix of emotions but also hope for the future. May we never forget and never allow this to happen again. Definitely worth a visit and just a short walk from the Brandenburg gate.
Just go. It's beautiful and haunting despite the people who use the installation as a seat or somewhere to eat lunch.....

I didn't find the idea of small grey blochhaus very kind for such a memorial wthout any name. Not the most interresting thing in Berlin
Queued up not too long to go in it's free admission. Includes obvious information on everything and individual personal family stories too.
You should know that most of the internal museum is a lot of reading 9n case you go with children. Overall it is very impressive and interesting.
One must visit this impressive memorial to appreciate the art installation and what it stands for Very clever Very moving

I am not Jewish, but this place will really takes you; this Memorial architecture is done in a way that slowly you will walk in the middle of hundreds of stones blocks...gives you a weird feeling ; very impressive.
We stopped at memorial during a walking tour. The memorial is designed tastefully to commemorate the holocaust victims.

a very special and unique memorial cite. lately it seems like visitors don't really understand the meaning of it, and look 'happy' to just get a 'selfy'. please get some infprmation or guidence before your visit, to be able to respect the victims... good to visit after seeing
At first glance this site appears quite strange. Then when you move among its stones you feel immediately emotional.

Somewhere everybody should go during their stay in Berlin. It really makes you think about what happened during the war. As our guide said you can read many things into the memorial and its significance.

A place that starts your thinking. Works for adults and kids. Beautiful in itself, but also raises questions: What do the concrete blocks symbolize, why are they lined up, why are they different in height? Fascinating place...
Thought provoking Holocaust Memorial, a quiet place to stop and think about your own interpretation of the memorial. Definitely worth a visit

As soon as you walk into the attraction, you can feel the significance of the space. It was really moving and it such a clever monument. Each person takes away from it what they think/feel.
Chilling monument. It was very well done and the interpretation a visitor is bound to come to is pretty universal if they know what they are visiting. A must...perhaps a brief one, but a must.

It's a thought provoking memorial. Some people meander through reflectively while others let their children run rampant. There are people guarding to ensure no one climbs on top. It's very busy but once you walk inside it it's not as noticeable. Definitely worth the stop.

Unusual memorial that you won’t forget, which is the whole point, whether you like it or not. There is more to it than you think as it covers a larger area than you can see initially and also it goes deep in the centre, giving it a claustrophobic sort of feeling too, reminiscent

Really heart breaking. Must visit when you're in Berlin. I recommend to go there when the sun goes down...

Spent a while wondering around the memorial. Really somber atmosphere. A must visit site in berlin recommend.
Suggest you take time to visit this thought provoking and well thought out monument if time permits.
For the memory of all those people who have died, this place is simple, quiet and have a lot of feelings.
The memorial depicted the horror of the holocaust by invoking images of caskets and a graveyard to represent the many people who died. Was touching in its simplicity with how the boxes were arranged.

This is a large memorial which brings home the numbers involved in the holocaust. It is well worth visiting and remembering all the terrible acts committed against the Jews in many European countries. A hard place to visit, but worthwhile.

Despite there being quite a few people here it was eerily quiet. A very moving memorial & interesting. It is well worth visiting & discovering the history behind it.
The holocaust memorial is like nothing I’ve ever seen before, very important part of German history displayed in a very architectural manner, must see attraction.

We visited in a group as part of the amazing Sandemans 3-Hour free walking tour. The memorial is very touching and has a beautiful and original design. Make sure you spend some minutes in this memorial!.

This landmark is one of the best in Berlin, highly recommended. Also you need to know the reason behind building the memorial like this, extremely meaningful...

This is a very powerful memorial. All European politicians should have to visit before they can take up office. A must visit.
Absolutely worth a trip as free and takes your breath away if you walk solo. There is a museum but a long queue.
I would recommend taking the time and visiting this memorial. It's quite powerful and worth the time to view it. It can get crowded but they manage the people entering quite nicely.

Very good place to visit and extremely moving and so sad. Well worth spending a few hours here as it has a huge amount of details in the museum.

Dropped off by coach at memorial - sense of awe and history when walking through the passageways - very clever sculpture idea.

Impressed by how Germans continue to educate and remind the world of the atrocities committed against the Jews.

This memorial is beautiful. In the middle of the bustling city it is quiet and peaceful. You can interpret so many meanings from what is here.
When you're in Berlin, you have to visit the monument and especially the museum underneath it! And take a audio tour, really impressive and makes you think!

Such a well designed memorial. Loved walking through and reflecting. There were so many people, but still serene.
What a great tribute to the murdered Jews and well done Germany and Berlin for this excellent site and wonderful museum (underneath the blocks) in the heart of the Capital City

It was fascinating to see all these granite(?) blocks laid out over a huge area representing the thousands of Jews killed in the Holocaust but why there? and why? Do the german population understand the memorial, I'm not sure I did.

We visited in autumn so the stark grey concrete blocks were framed by the back drop of beautiful autumnal trees This is a lovely place to wander and gather thoughts and To muse on the atrocities. I would recommend people visit
A special monument with different sized cubes. Centrally located in Berlin, close to Brandenburger Tor.

Very honest and eye-opening experience to go to see this memorial with the exhibition underground - so many things to learn and its all very well presented - definitely recommend.

We went because it was there .... but it was so much more. You just have to go ..... so go The museum compliments the memorial so beautifully

After our visit to the Reichstag we wandered by this memorial. Amazing place with all the concrete blocks. Whilst we didn't go into the museum the place was very moving - imagining what this was commemorating. Definitely well worth a visit.

Very impressive description of the horrible things that happened there. Great way of sharing it in a very simple tribute to those that died there.

I had never heard of this memorial, until I came across it during a tour in Berlin. I was so taken with it, that I walked over there after the bus tour was over. It is big, beautiful, compelling, and photogenic. You could get lost in your thoughts walking amongst the columns.
Can not say enough on how moving it was. going through the memorial was jaw dropping when you try to think about why the memorial was made the way it was
